sen.j: 仲哀天皇（ちゅうあいてんのう、生年不詳 - 仲哀天皇9年2月6日 (旧暦)（200年3月8日））は、『古事記』『日本書紀』に記される第14代の天皇（在位：仲哀天皇元年1月11日 (旧暦)（192年2月11日） - 同9年2月6日（200年3月8日））。
sen.e: Emperor Chuai (year of birth unknown - March 8, 200) is the fourteenth Emperor who is recorded on "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) (period of reign: February 11, 192 - March 8, 200).

Emperor Chuai (year of birth unknown - March 8, 200) was the fourteenth Emperor of Japan, as recorded in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) (period of reign: February 11, 192 - March 8, 200).

Emperor Chuai (year of birth unknown - March 8, 200) was the fourteenth Emperor of Japan, as recorded in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) (period of reign: February 11, 192 - March 8, 200).

sen.j: 足仲彦天皇（たらしなかつひこのすめらみこと）、帯中日子天皇（古事記）。
sen.e: He is also called Tarashinakatsuhiko no Sumeramikoto, and written 足仲彦天皇 or 帯中日子天皇 (Kojiki).
sen.cmt: 書き方そのものが話題となっている為漢字を使用しました。
sen.e: He is also called Tarashinakatsuhiko no Sumeramikoto, and written 足仲彦天皇 or 帯中日子天皇 (Kojiki).
sen.cmt: "and written"→"which was written either" - I'm not sure the kanji are necessary or helpful for most English speakers and could be deleted
sen.e: He was also called Tarashinakatsuhiko no Sumeramikoto, and written 足仲彦天皇 or 帯中日子天皇 (Kojiki).

sen.j: 「タラシヒコ」という称号は12代景行、13代成務、14代仲哀の3天皇が持ち、ずっと下がって7世紀前半に在位したことの確実な34代舒明、35代皇極の両天皇も同じ称号をもつことから、タラシヒコの称号は7世紀前半のものであり、12,13,14代の称号は後世の造作ということになり、仲哀天皇の実在性には疑問が出されている（仲哀天皇架空説）。
sen.e: The title 'Tarashihiko' is held by the twelfth Emperor Keiko, the thirteenth Emperor Seimu, and the fourteenth Emperor Chuai, but since both the thirty-fourth Emperor Jomei and the thirty-fifth Emperor Kogyoku, who are sure to be existed far after time in the early half of 7th century, also hold the same title, the title Tarashihiko is regarded as one in the early half of the 7th century, which makes the title of twelfth, thirteenth, and fourteenth Emperor a creation in the later history, giving doubts to the actual existence of Emperor Chuai (theory regarding Emperor Chuai as a fictional person).

The title 'Tarashihiko' was held by the twelfth Emperor, Keiko, the thirteenth Emperor, Seimu, and the fourteenth Emperor, Chuai, although this title is believed to have come into use in the early seventh century, when it was used by the thirty-fourth Emperor, Jomei and the thirty-fifth Emperor, Kogyoku, both of whom are known to have existed, and added later to the twelfth, thirteenth, and fourteenth Emperors, raising doubts about the actual existence of Emperor Chuai (theory of Emperor Chuai as a fictional person).

The title 'Tarashihiko' was held by the twelfth Emperor, Keiko, the thirteenth Emperor, Seimu, and the fourteenth Emperor, Chuai, although this title is believed to have come into use in the early seventh century, when it was used by the thirty-fourth Emperor, Jomei and the thirty-fifth Emperor, Kogyoku, both of whom are known to have existed, and added later to the twelfth, thirteenth, and fourteenth Emperors, raising doubts about the actual existence of Emperor Chuai (theory of Emperor Chuai as a fictional person).

sen.j: 神功皇后の夫・応神天皇の父とされるが、実在性を含めて諸事績の史実性には疑いが持たれる。
sen.e: He is regarded as the husband of Empress Jingu and the father of Emperor Ojin, but there are doubts held against the certainty of his actual achievements as historical facts, including his actual existence.
He is regarded as the husband of Empress Jingu and the father of Emperor Ojin, but there are doubts over the certainty of his actual achievements as historical facts, including his actual existence.
He was regarded as the husband of Empress Jingu and the father of Emperor Ojin, but there are doubts over the certainty of his actual achievements as historical facts, including his actual existence.
sen.cmt: 一部過去形にしました。

sen.j: 長門国豊浦宮（あなとのとゆらのみや、山口県下関市長府宮の内町の忌宮神社が伝承地）
sen.e: Anato no Toyura no Miya (Iminomiya-jinja Shrine in Chofumiyanouchi Town, Shimonoseki City, Yamaguchi Prefecture is transmitted as the former palace).
Anato no Toyura no Miya (traditionally believed to be where Iminomiya-jinja Shrine in Chofumiyanouchi Town, Shimonoseki City, Yamaguchi Prefecture now stands).
sen.cmt: "is transmitted as the former palace"→"traditionally believed to be where" and movedAdded "now stands"
sen.e: Anato no Toyura no Miya (traditionally believed to be where Iminomiya-jinja Shrine in Chofumiyanouchi Town, Shimonoseki City, Yamaguchi Prefecture now stands).

sen.j: 筑紫国橿日宮（つくしのかしいのみや、福岡県福岡市東区 (福岡市)香椎の香椎宮が伝承地）
sen.e: Tsukushi no Kashii no Miya (Kashii-gu Shrine in Kashii, Higashi Ward, Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture is transmitted as the former palace).
Tsukushi no Kashii no Miya (traditionally believed to be where Kashii-gu Shrine in Kashii, Higashi Ward, Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture now stands).
sen.cmt: "is transmitted as the former palace"→"traditionally believed to be where" and movedAdded "now stands"
sen.e: Tsukushi no Kashii no Miya (traditionally believed to be where Kashii-gu Shrine in Kashii, Higashi-ku Ward, Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture now stands).

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によれば叔父の成務天皇に嗣子が無く、成務天皇48年3月1日（178年）に31歳で立太子。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," since his uncle, Emperor Seimu, didn't have a heir, he was instituted as the Crown Prince on March 1, 178, when he was thirty-one.
According to the "Nihonshoki," since his uncle, Emperor Seimu, didn't have a heir, he was invested as Crown Prince on March 1, 178, when he was thirty-one.
According to the Nihon Shoki, Emperor Chuai was chosen as Crown Prince at the age of 31, because his uncle, Emperor Seimu had no heir.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 13年の皇太子期間を経て、仲哀天皇元年1月（192年）即位。
sen.e: After going through period of thirteen years as the Crown Prince, in January 192, he was enthroned.
After thirteen years as Crown Prince, he was made Emperor in January 192.
sen.cmt: Deleted " going through period of", "the""he was enthroned"→"he was made Emperor" and moved
sen.e: After thirteen years as Crown Prince, he was made Emperor in January 192.

sen.j: 白鳥となって天に昇った父日本武尊（景行天皇43年（113年）死去）をしのんで、諸国に白鳥を献じることを命じたが、異母弟の蘆髪蒲見別王が越国の献じた白鳥を奪ったため誅殺したとある。
sen.e: It is recorded that as a memorial for his father Yamato Takeru no Mikoto (died in 113), who flew up in the sky as a swan, he ordered every provinces to present swans, but since Ashikamino Kamami Wakenomiko, his young half-brother, robbed the swans presented by Koshi Province, he killed him for the punishment.

To commemorate his father Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, who died in 113 and flew to heaven as a swan, he ordered every province to present some swans, and when Ashikamino Kamami Wakenomiko, his younger half-brother, stole the swans presented by Koshi Province, he executed him.
sen.cmt: "It is recorded that as a memorial for"→"To commemorate" - Japanese doesn't have "It is recorded"Added "who"Deleted brackets"who"→"and""up in the sky"→"to heaven"Made "provinces" singular"but since"→"and when""young"→"younger""robbed "→"stole""killed him for the punishment"→"executed him"
sen.e: To commemorate his father Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, who died in 113 and flew to heaven as a swan, he ordered every province to present some swans, and when Ashikamino Kamami Wakenomiko, his younger half-brother, stole the swans presented by Koshi Province, he executed him.

sen.j: 仲哀天皇2年1月11日（193年）、仲哀天皇は氣長足姫尊（成務天皇40年（170年）誕生）を皇后（神功皇后）とする。
sen.e: On January 11, 193, Emperor Chuai made Okinagatarashi Himeno Mikoto (born in 170) as the Empress (Empress Jingu).
On January 11, 193, Emperor Chuai made Okinagatarashi Himeno Mikoto (born in 170) his Empress (Empress Jingu).
On February 28, 193, Emperor Chuai made Okinagatarashi Himeno Mikoto (born in 170) his Empress (Empress Jingu).

sen.j: 8年（199年）熊襲討伐のため神功皇后とともに筑紫に赴いた仲哀天皇は、憑依した神功皇后から住吉大神のお告げを受けた。
sen.e: In 199, to subjugate Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district) he went to Chikushi with Empress Jingu, and received an oracle from Empress Jingu who was possessed by Sumiyoshi Okami (the great gods of Sumiyoshi).

In 199, to subjugate the Kumaso (a tribe who lived in Kyushu), he went to Chikushi (in present-day Fukuoka) with Empress Jingu, receiving an oracle from the Empress, who was possessed by Sumiyoshi Okami (the three great gods of Sumiyoshi).
sen.cmt: Added "the""living"→"who lived in"Deleted "ancient", "district"Added "(in present-day Fukuoka)""and received"→"receiving"Added "the"Deleted "Jingu"Added comma, "three"
sen.e: In 199 A.D., when visiting Chikushi (present-day Fukuoka, Kyushu) together with Empress Jingu in order to conquer the Kumaso (a rebellious group living in Kyushu), Emperor Chuai received an oracle from the empress, who was possessed by Sumiyoshi Okami (three great gods of Sumiyoshi).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: それは西海の宝の国（新羅のこと）を授けるという神託であった。
sen.e: It was an oracle giving the treasure country in the western sea (Shilla).
The oracle said he would receive the country of treasure in the Western Sea, (meaning Silla, in present-day South Korea).
The oracle told him that he would be given a land of treasure in the western sea (Silla, present-day South Korea).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、仲哀天皇は、これを信じず住吉大神を非難した。
sen.e: However, Emperor Chuai didn't believe this and criticized it.
However, Emperor Chuai didn't believe it and criticized the three gods.
However, Emperor Chuai didn't believe it and criticized the Sumiyoshi Okami gods.
sen.cmt: 住吉大神を訳出しました。

sen.j: そのため神の怒りに触れ、仲哀天皇は翌年2月に急死してしまった。
sen.e: Because of that, he incurred the gods' indignations and suddenly died in February of the next year.
As a result, he incurred the gods' wrath and died suddenly in February the following year.
sen.cmt: "Because of that"→"As a result""indignations"→"wrath"Moved "died""of the next"→"the following"
sen.e: As a result, he incurred the gods' wrath and died suddenly in February the following year.

sen.j: 遺体は武内宿禰により海路穴門を通って豊浦宮で殯された。
sen.e: His corpse was sent by sea route through Anato and was kept temporarily at Toyura no Miya.
His corpse was sent by sea via Anato (present-day Yamaguchi) and was kept temporarily at Toyura no Miya.
His corpse was sent by sea via Anato (present-day Yamaguchi) and was kept temporarily at Toyura no Miya by TAKEUCHI no Sukune.
sen.cmt: 武内宿禰を補足しました。

sen.j: 『（『天書紀』では熊襲の矢が当たったという。
sen.e: (According to "Tenshoki," arrow by Kumaso hit him
(According to the "Tenshoki," he was shot by a Kumaso arrow
sen.cmt: Added "the""arrow by Kumaso hit him"→"he wsa shot by a Kumaso arrow""
sen.e: (According to the "Tenshoki" (Records of the Tensho Era), he was shot by a Kumaso arrow.

sen.j: 『古事記』に「凡そ帯中日津子天皇の御年、五十二歳。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," it is recorded that 'the age of Tarashinakatsuhiko no Sumeramikoto was about fifty-two.
In the "Kojiki," it is recorded that 'the age of Tarashinakatsuhiko no Sumeramikoto was fifty-two.
In the "Kojiki," it is recorded that 'the age of Tarashinakatsuhiko no Sumeramikoto was fifty-two.

sen.j: 壬戌の年の六月十一日に崩りましき」。
sen.e: Died on June 11, in the year of Mizunoe Inu.'
He died on June 11, in the year of Mizunoe Inu.'
sen.cmt: Added "He"- Left "Mizunoe Inu" as it is but maybe "the Year of the Dog" is better
sen.e: He died on June 11 in the year of the Water-Dog in the sixty-year Chinese calendar cycle.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』にも52歳とするが、これから逆算すると、天皇は父ヤマトタケルの薨後36年目に生まれたこととなり、矛盾する。
sen.e: It is recorded as fifty-two in "Nihonshoki," too, but if counted backwards, the Emperor should be born thirty-six years after the death of his father Yamato Takeru, and contradiction is made.
The "Nihonshoki" also records an age of fifty-two but, if counted backwards, this results in the paradox of the Emperor being born thirty-six years after the death of his father.
The "Nihonshoki" also records an age of fifty-two but, if counted backwards, this results in the paradox of the Emperor being born thirty-six years after the death of Yamato Takeru, his father.

sen.j: 「この御世に、淡道（あわじ）の屯家（みやけ）を定めたまひき。
sen.e: Established Miyake in Awaji during this period.
He 'established Miyake in Awaji during this period.
He established Miyake (manors under the direct control of the dynasty) in Awaji during this period.'
("Kojiki")
("Kojiki")
("Kojiki")

sen.j: 元年二月条に「即月に、淡路の屯倉を定む。
sen.e: In article of February of the first year, 'Established Miyake in Awaji this month.
In the entry for February of the first year, 'he established Miyake in Awaji this month.'
sen.cmt: " article of"→"the entry for"Added "He" and quote mark
sen.e: It is written in an entry in the Kojiki for February of the first year that he established an imperial territory (called "miyake" in Japanese) in Awaji.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 」（『日本書紀』）
sen.e: ("Nihonshoki")
("Nihonshoki")
("Nihonshoki")

sen.j: 屯倉は、朝廷直轄の農業経営地あるいは直轄領。
sen.e: Miyake is a land for agricultural management under the direct control of Imperial Court, or territory under the direct control.
Miyake is agricultural land under the direct control of Imperial Court, or a directly controlled fief.
sen.cmt: "a land for agricultural management"→"agricultural land""territory under the direct control"→"a directly controled fief"
sen.e: Miyake is agricultural land under the direct control of Imperial Court, or a directly controlled fief.

tit.e: Theory regarding Emperor Chuai as fictional person
Theory of Emperor Chuai as a fictional person
Theory of Emperor Chuai as a fictional person

sen.j: 歴史学者の間では、仲哀天皇は実在性の低い天皇の一人に挙げられている。
sen.e: Among historians, Emperor Chuai is counted as one of the Emperors with low possibility of actual existence.
Historians count Emperor Chuai as an Emperor with a low possibility of actual existence.
sen.cmt: Deleted "Among""is counted"→"count" and moved"one of the Emperors"→"an Emperor"Added "a"
sen.e: Historians count Emperor Chuai as an Emperor with a low possibility of actual existence.

sen.j: その最も大きな根拠は、実在性のほとんど無い父（日本武尊）と妻（神功皇后）をもっている人物であるため、とされている。
sen.e: Its biggest basis is regarded as that he is a person with father (Yamato Takeru no Mikoto) and wife (Emperor Jingu) with almost no possibility for actual existence.
The main reason for this is that both his father (Yamato Takeru no Mikoto) and his wife (Empress Jingu) almost certainly did not exist.
The main reason for this is that both his father (Yamato Takeru no Mikoto) and his wife (Empress Jingu) almost certainly did not exist.

sen.j: 日本武尊の話は複数の大和地方の英雄の事跡を小碓命（おうすのみこと）一人にあてがって、一大英雄伝説に仕立て上げた物であり、神功皇后の話は白村江の戦いから、持統天皇による文武天皇擁立までの経緯をもとに神話として記紀に挿入された物である、としている。
sen.e: They regard the stories of Yamato Takeru no Mikoto as a great legend of hero made out by putting plural facts about heroes in Yamato region to one person, Osu no Mikoto, and stories of Empress Jingu as myth, based on sequence of events from the Battle of Hakusukinoe through the enthronement of Emperor Monmu by Empress Jito, inserted into Kiki (Kojiki and Nihonshoki).

The stories of Yamato Takeru and Empress Jingu are thought to have been inserted into the Kojki and Nihonshoki, with Yamato Takeru believed to be based on legends of Yamato heroes, condensed into the person of Prince Mikoto, and Empress Jingu's story to be based on the sequence of events from the Battle of Hakusukinoe through the enthronement of Emperor Monmu by Empress Jito.

The stories of Yamato Takeru and Empress Jingu are thought to have been inserted into the Kojiki and Nihonshoki, with Yamato Takeru believed to be based on legends of heroes in Yamato region, condensed into the person of Osu no Mikoto, and Empress Jingu's story to be based on the sequence of events from the Battle of Hakusukinoe through the enthronement of Emperor Monmu by Empress Jito.
sen.cmt: スペルなどを修正しました。

sen.j: そしてこれらの架空の人物群とそれにまつわる物語とを史実として正当化するために、仲哀天皇が架空に作り上げられ記紀に挿入された、とするのが仲哀天皇架空説である。
sen.e: And the theory which regards Emperor Chuai as fictional person assumes that Emperor Chuai was fictionally made up and inserted into Kiki to justify these fictional personalities and stories among them as historical facts.

The theory of Emperor Chuai as a fictional person asserts that Emperor Chuai was invented and inserted into the Kojki and Nihonshoki to justify these fictional personalities and their stories as historical fact.
sen.cmt: Deleted "and""which regards"→"of"Added "a""assumes"→"asserts""fictionally made up"→"invented""Kiki"→"the Kojki and Nihonshoki""stories among them"→"their stories"Made "facts" singular
sen.e: The theory of Emperor Chuai as a fictional person asserts that Emperor Chuai was invented and inserted into the Kojiki and Nihonshoki to justify these fictional personalities and their stories as historical fact.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: また、タラシナカツヒコ（足仲彦・帯中日子）という和風諡号から尊称のタラシヒコを除くと、ナカツという名が残るが、これは抽象名詞であって実名とは言えない（天智天皇のように、通常は普通名詞的な別名に使われる）。
sen.e: Also, if honorific title Tarashihiko is removed from his Japanese Shigo (posthumous name) Tarashinakatsuhiko, the name Nakatsu remains, but this is an abstract noun and can't be said as actual name (like Emperor Tenchi, it is normally used on another name in means of common noun).

Also, if the honorific title Tarashihiko is removed from his Shigo (posthumous name), Tarashinakatsuhiko, the name Nakatsu remains, but this is an abstract noun and can't be said to be an actual name (usually, extra names are based on common nouns, as was the case with Emperor Tenchi).
sen.cmt: Added "the"Deleted "Japanese" - although original has "和風", I don't think it's necessary for non-Japanese people"as"→"to be an"Reworded section in brackets for clarity
sen.e: Also, if the honorific title Tarashihiko is removed from his Shigo (posthumous name), Tarashinakatsuhiko, the name Nakatsu remains, but this is an abstract noun and can't be said to be an actual name (usually, extra names are based on common nouns, as was the case with Emperor Tenchi).

sen.j: つまり、仲哀天皇の和風諡号は実名を元にした物ではなく、抽象的な普通名詞と言う事になる。
sen.e: In other words, the Japanese Shigo of Emperor Chuai is not based on an actual name, and it should be an abstract common noun.
In other words, the Shigo of Emperor Chuai is not based on an actual name, but is an abstract common noun.
sen.cmt: Deleted "Japanese""and it should be an"→"but is"
sen.e: In other words, the Shigo of Emperor Chuai is not based on an actual name, but is an abstract common noun.

sen.j: さらに前述の通り、『日本書紀』では父日本武尊の死後36年も経ってから生まれたことになる不自然な証拠からも、仲哀天皇架空説は根強く言われている。
sen.e: Also like mentioned above, in "Nihonshoki," there is an unnatural evidence making him born after thirty-six years after his father Yamato Takeru no Mikoto's death, and the theory regarding Emperor Chuai as fictional person is tenaciously advanced.

Also, as mentioned above, the unnatural evidence in the "Nihonshoki" that points to him being born thirty-six years after the death of his father, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, is often used to support the theory that he was a fictional character.

Also, as mentioned above, the unnatural evidence in the "Nihonshoki" that points to him being born thirty-six years after the death of his father, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, is often used to support the theory that he was a fictional character.

sen.j: 恵我長野西陵（えがのながののにしのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: He was buried in Egano Nagano no Nishi no Misasagi.
He was buried in Egano Nagano no Nishi no Misasagi.
He was buried in Ega no Nagano no Nishi no Misasagi.

sen.j: 日本書紀に「河内国長野陵」、古事記には「御陵は河内の恵賀（えが）の長江にあり」とする。
sen.e: In Nihonshoki, it is recorded as 'Nagano Misasagi in Kawachi Province,' and in Kojiki, it is recorded that 'misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) is at Nagae in Ega of Kawachi.'
In Nihonshoki, it is recorded as 'Nagano Misasagi in Kawachi Province,' and in Kojiki, it is recorded that 'misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) is at Nagae in Ega of Kawachi.'
In Nihonshoki, it is recorded as 'Nagano no Misasagi in Kawachi Province,' and in Kojiki, it is recorded that 'misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) is at Nagae in Ega of Kawachi.'

sen.j: 同陵は大阪府藤井寺市の岡ミサンザイ古墳（前方後円墳）に比定される。
sen.e: This mausoleum is commonly compared with Okaminzai Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound) in Fujiidera City, Osaka Prefecture.
This mausoleum is commonly compared with Okaminzai Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound) in Fujiidera City, Osaka Prefecture.
This mausoleum is estimated to be the Okamisanzai tumulus (a circular tumulus with a rectangular frontage) located in Fujiidera City, Osaka Prefecture.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 幅50m以上の周濠が巡らされているが、中世に城砦として利用されていたため、部分的に改変されている。
sen.e: It is surrounded by moat with more than fifty meters in width, but since it was used as a fortress in the Medieval Period, it is partly changed.
It is surrounded by moat with more than fifty meters in width, but since it was used as a fortress in the Medieval Period, it is partly changed.
It is surrounded by a moat with a width of more than fifty meters; however, it was partly renovated in medieval times to be used as a fortress.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
